pages.text: Herrerasaurus ischigualastensis is a species of primitive theropod dinosaur or non-dinosaur dinosaurimorph from the Late Triassic of Argentina.  Around 3-4 m long, this carnivorous animal represented a medium sized predator in his habitat, hunting a variety of animals among them the slow and cumbersome Rhynchosaurs.

Herrerasaurus is known from several partial skeletons from the Ischigualasto formation, its remains discovered alongside other dinosaurian fauna like the small Eoraptor lunensis and potentially one of the first ornithischians, Pisanosaurus mertii.

Originally described in 1963 by Osvaldo Reig, Herrerasaurus remained a mystery for many years, with its uncertain classification only being clarified further in 1988, when a more complete skull revealed the animal to have been potentially an early saurischian, a hypothesis several researchers subscribed to since then.

Due to its unclear status and recent research in archosaurian integumentary coverings, it’s not certain if the animal could’ve had primitive filamentous covering or if it was naked, as such the way we represented this animal offers a potential view of a hypothetical state of development,
where early dinosaurimorphs could’ve had body covering, however this may be subject to change as our knowledge on these incredible animals develops further.
